speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.1: COVID Mask Policy - The board will discuss the district’s COVID-19 health protocols, specifically whether students should be required to wear masks while in classrooms. This policy would apply during the regular school day, with exceptions for lunch and designated mask-break periods. The goal is to balance student safety with comfort and learning effectiveness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Thanks, Graham. I'm concerned about how the current case rates affect our ability to keep kids safe.  

I wonder if anyone has data on what percentage of students who test positive were actually symptomatic or had severe outcomes.  

Maybe it's worth asking our medical director again—how much does masking really reduce transmission at school versus other settings?  

Kate, could you confirm that we've still got consistent testing availability across all buildings?  

I think we should consider whether there's evidence that unmasked classrooms are leading to higher absenteeism due to illness.  

If so, maybe we need stronger guidance—even if it feels uncomfortable right now.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you David. I agree with you, and I guess my question is what kind of metrics do we want to look at? Because certainly we know cases are up. And yes, we're seeing more than twice the number of cases compared to last year. But the impact on schools, I mean, I suspect most of them are asymptomatic.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate. I appreciate your perspective.  

David, I’d love to hear your thoughts on how we’re measuring those impacts beyond just case counts—do we have any data on symptom severity among students who tested positive?

And Kate, could you please check if we’ve updated our risk assessment model since March?  

I’m wondering too—if we haven’t seen widespread absences tied to infections, does that suggest our mitigation strategies are working?  

Would someone mind sharing the latest numbers on staff or student absences linked directly to illness?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Judi. That’s a good point—I wonder if we’ve looked at absenteeism trends specifically tied to confirmed cases versus general cold/flu patterns.

Kate, could you pull together the recent absence data broken down by cause?  

Also, David, when you mentioned symptom severity earlier—did we get anything back from the medical director on that?

Judie, was there something specific about the risk assessment model you wanted clarified?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thank you, Ellen. I wonder if Dr. Pfeiffer has done any modeling around the risks associated with indoor activities in schools. Maybe we should ask her to join us next week.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Thank you, Jonno. I appreciate you bringing that up. It seems like a great idea. Do you think we can schedule that?

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Thanks, Ellen. I appreciate your focus on symptoms—it’s easy to miss that even mild cases can disrupt learning.
Judie, I think we should definitely revisit the risk model. Could you assign someone to check its validity against current data?
Ellen, I’ll bet we don’t track absences by *cause* very well. Is that something we can fix quickly?
Jonno, I agree—we should bring Dr. Pfeiffer in. Katrina, why don't you reach out to her office today and see if she’s available next week?
Katrina, can you also ask if she’s comfortable presenting virtually, in case others can’t attend in person?

speaker: kateacuff
content: David, I'd like to know what the guidelines are for quarantining after exposure. Are they different for vaccinated versus unvaccinated individuals?

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate.  
David, could you clarify—when did we last update those quarantine guidelines?  
Katrina, would you please check if Dr. Pfeiffer is available for next Wednesday at 6 PM?  
And David, could you confirm whether we’re currently tracking exposures by vaccine status?  
I’d also like to understand better how we’re defining “close contact” under the new rules.

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Judi. That’s helpful—could we double-check how close contacts are defined right now?
Katrina, would you please confirm if we’re tracking exposures by vaccination status?  
David, can you help us find out when those quarantine guidelines were last revised?  
Judie, I’d appreciate knowing how strict the definition of “close contact” is—is it based on duration, proximity, or both?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Judith, could you please remind me which criteria define a close contact? I seem to remember there being several factors involved.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Ellen and Jonno.
I think we should verify whether "close contact" includes shared air space without direct face-to-face interaction—does that count?
Could someone please confirm if we’re using CDC definitions or updating them locally?
And Ellen, would you mind checking if we have real-time data on exposure logs per building?
Judie, can you assign someone to review the current exposure thresholds and report back by Friday?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Sure, Judi. I will assign that task to someone.

speaker: judyle
content: Thanks, Katrina. Please make sure it’s someone familiar with the protocol—would you please confirm that?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yes, I'll make sure that happens.

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Judi, I appreciate your diligence here—this is exactly the level of detail we need.
Katrina, I think we should flag this issue with the health department—can you please draft a note to them asking if we’re aligned on exposure definitions?
Judie, I’m not sure we’re capturing exposure logs consistently. Could you confirm whether each building submits reports weekly?
Ellen, I wonder if we’re missing data because some families aren’t reporting exposures. Should we send a reminder to parents?
Jonno, I’d hate to assume we’re doing everything right—let’s make sure we’re not overlooking gaps.

speaker: kateacuff
content: David, I'm concerned that our guidance says that children exposed to a case outside of school can return to class after five days—but we require isolation for ten days if infected. I wonder if we need to reconsider that difference in timing.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate.
That’s a fair concern—David, could you look into whether the ten-day rule applies uniformly across all cases?
I wonder if we’re sending mixed messages to families by having different timelines for exposure vs. infection.
Can someone check if the health department supports that distinction?
Judie, would you please assign someone to compare the two timelines side-by-side and explain the reasoning behind them?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Kate. That’s a solid point—do we actually know why the timelines differ?
Judie, could you please check if the health department explains that variation somewhere?
David, can you help us find out whether the ten-day rule applies the same way for everyone?
Judie, let’s make sure we’re not confusing families with inconsistent messaging.
Is there anyone else who thinks this timeline mismatch might be worth revisiting?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Judy, I really want to hear what the health department's thinking is on these differences. Would you please check with them?

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Jonno.
I agree—David, can you please get clarity from the health department on the rationale for differing isolation periods?
Judie, could you follow up with them and report back by Monday?
And Ellen, would you please confirm whether the guidance document explicitly states the logic behind the timeline split?
We should make sure families understand the reasoning—not just the rules.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Okay, I can check on that.

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Judi, I think we should pause before finalizing anything—if the rationale isn’t clear, we shouldn’t expect families to accept it.  
Kate, I agree—this inconsistency could confuse parents. Could you assign someone to dig into the source of those timelines?  
Ellen, maybe we should rephrase the guidance so it doesn’t sound arbitrary. Would you please suggest edits?  
Judie, since you’ve been leading this, can you confirm we’re all on the same page about the purpose of isolation?  
I worry we’re making assumptions without evidence. Let’s keep digging until we’re confident.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I am wondering if we're ready to consider relaxing any mask mandates, given the drop in case rates.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate.
I think we should wait until we see sustained low transmission over multiple weeks.
David, could you monitor case trends by school and report back monthly?
Judie, would you please check if staff and students feel safe wearing masks indoors?
And Ellen, could you survey families about comfort levels with masking?
Let’s not rush—our goal is safety, not speed.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote publicly.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.1: Should the district require students to wear masks in classrooms during the school day?.  Mr. Oberg, can you please start us off?

speaker: davidoberg
content: no

speaker: grahampaige
content: Mr. Oberg votes no.  Thank you, Mr. Oberg.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Acuff, your turn.

speaker: kateacuff
content:
The data suggests declining cases, but I don't know how reliable it is because many people aren't testing anymore.
Also, some kids still have severe symptoms even after five days.
So while there may be less risk of spreading, there might be more risk to their own health.
I'd like to continue requiring masks for another month or two.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Acuff votes abstain.  Thank you, Ms. Acuff.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Le, your turn.

speaker: judyle
content: no

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Le votes no.  Thank you, Ms. Le.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Osborne, your turn.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Osborne votes yes.  Thank you, Ms. Osborne.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Jonnoalcaro, your turn.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: no

speaker: grahampaige
content: Jonnoalcaro votes no.  Thank you, Jonnoalcaro.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Callsen, your turn.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ms. Callsen votes yes.  Thank you, Ms. Callsen.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Now it's my turn to vote.

speaker: grahampaige
content: I'm sorry, but I was not present when we had this discussion. So based upon what has been said by others, I would like to vote no.
